intro: Spermacoce pilifera, commonly known as the hairy false morning glory, is a flowering plant native to tropical and subtropical regions of Africa, Asia, and the Americas. It is a member of the Rubiaceae family and typically grows as an annual herb with slender, erect stems. The plant produces small, white or pale blue flowers that are clustered in umbels, and its leaves are opposite, ovate, and often hairy. Its fruits are dry, dehiscent capsules that release tiny seeds when mature. Spermacoce pilifera is often found in disturbed soils and is sometimes considered a weed in agricultural settings.
